Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Cyber Physical Regional Freight Transportation System Start

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop optimization and control techniques and integrate them with real-time simulation models to achieve load balancing in complex networks. The application case is the regional freight system. Freight moves on rail and road networks which are also shared by passengers. These networks today work independently, even though they are highly interdependent, and the result is inefficiencies in the form of congestion, pollution, and excess fuel consumption. These inefficiencies are observed for example by the peaks of demand across time and space. Inefficiencies exist in part due to lack of information and appropriate tools, and in part due to lack of policies and institutional structures that would promote more integrated operations. The problem is made even more complex due to the large quantities of real time data that will be available to inform the decision-making.

This research develops the theoretical foundations of a new approach referred to as COSMO to balance loads across complex dynamical networks with temporal and spacial characteristics. In contrast to current practices where simple mathematical models are used to predict the states of the network the method employs computational simulation models that are far more accurate in estimating the states of the network by taking into account dynamics and complex interactions. The project develops the optimization and load balancing control segments of the cyber physical system and integrate them with real time network simulation models using freight transportation as the driving application area. The research also examines how identified barriers and policy issues/incentives can be incorporated as mathematical constraints and/or control variables in the optimized dynamic freight load balancing system. Data supporting the analysis may include freight characterization, traffic, weather, and other large data volumes. The project will utilize real time data from the port of Los Angeles /Long Beach area to validate the approach. The port of Los Angeles/Long Beach is the port of entry for much of the freight that enters the West Coast, and provides rich sets of data that will stimulate the model especially in regional transportation involving interaction between road/rail/port networks. This fundamental technology in this important transportation domain with direct applications to other large scale freight centers, can be applied to other application domains including networking and smart grid. Besides the broader impact derived from more efficient allocation of transportation resources, the project also provide educational outreach and produce course modules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project is to develop optimization and control techniques and integrate them with real-time simulation models to achieve load balancing – the optimal allocation of demand across routes, time periods, and modes -- in regional freight networks. The outcomes of the project are as follows:

Intellectual Merit: A co-simulation optimization control (COSMO) approach is developed that takes full advantage of computer memory and computational speeds in order to solve complex problems that cannot be accurately modeled using traditionally simple mathematical models. One such complex problem is routing freight in a multimodal network that includes road and rail networks, the application area of this project.  The nonlinear dependence of loads on the states of the network is captured by the co-simulation approach. Users communicate their demand to a central coordinator who generates optimum routes by minimizing an overall social cost. It is well known that the societal optimum may impose additional costs on some individuals relative to user optimum routing. Incentives for participation and user truthfulness are modeled as constraints in a way that guarantees that the user will always benefit by participating rather than not. A pricing scheme is established to achieve fairness and guarantee overall benefits. In order to deal with complexity and scalability issues the large network is partitioned into subnetworks. Partitioning reduces computational load but increases deviation from optimality. We identify these trade-offs, and show that the decentralized COSMO approach can be integrated to provide near optimal centralized decisions.   

The proposed freight load balancing system has been demonstrated using a simulation testbed that covers a large road and rail network in the Southern California area. It includes the twin ports of Los Angeles/Long Beach and has a high volume of freight traffic.  The testbed allows for simulations under different traffic conditions and demands. The results show that a centrally coordinated freight load balancing system based on the COSMO approach has a strong potential for providing better routing decisions, resulting in lower costs and air toxic emissions.

Broader Impact:The ultimate goal of this research is to develop methods for freight load balancing that can be implemented and hence increase the efficiency and sustainability of freight transport. The feasibility of such a system was explored via reviews of prior studies on freight mode, time window, and routing behavior. We also conducted in-depth interviews with fleet managers and drivers to understand potential barriers to implementation.  These include the fragmentation and complexity of the freight transport industry, customer driven constraints, labor issues, and unwillingness to cede control to a central decision-maker.

The weekly meetings throughout the duration of the project helped bring together graduate students from Electrical, Industrial Engineering and Urban Planning to interact on the multidisciplinary problem of freight transport. Interactions with stakeholders via meetings and interviews gave a chance to introduce the project and get feedback with respect to its practical significance. Several undergraduate students worked with PhD students on various aspects of the project. Community college students visited the lab while two elementary school teachers in the neighborhood spent a month in our lab learning about the project and results and how to incorporate some of the high level ideas or demonstrations into their teaching curriculum.
